supply.translation[0].definitions[0].def: an amount of something that is available to be used
supply.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The nation’s fuel supplies will not last forever.
To protect the food supply, the government ordered the slaughter of affected cattle.
There was a plentiful supply of cheap labour.
I’ve only got a week’s supply of tablets left.
supply.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The military government is trying to stop the supply of guns to the rebels.
supply.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: a good supply
In hot countries, always carry a good supply of water.
a plentiful/abundant supply
There was a plentiful supply of books and magazines to read.
an adequate supply
The larger cities usually have more modern health facilities and an adequate supply of medicines.
a constant/steady/regular supply
For dairy farming, a constant supply of lush grass is essential.
an endless/inexhaustible supply
He has an endless supply of jokes.
a ready supply
The early settlers also found a ready supply of flints in the chalk cliffs.
a small/limited supply
There is a limited supply of land for building.
a dwindling supply
We cannot rely on the dwindling supplies of crude oil and natural gas.
a fresh supply
A fresh supply of fuel was needed.
use up/exhaust a supply
The diver had nearly used up his supply of oxygen.
supply.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to provide people with something that they need or want, especially regularly over a long period of time
supply.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Paint for the project was supplied by the city.
An informer supplied the police with the names of those involved in the crime.
They were arrested for supplying drugs to street dealers.
supply.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to provide goods or services to customers, especially regularly and over a long period of time
supply.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: In certain circumstances they will charge an additional amount when supplying agricultural goods and services.
The company supplies products and services to the energy industry.
The computer giant has agreed to supply Mitsubishi with mainframe and minicomputers.
supply.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to give someone something they want or need
supply.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Several pharmaceutical companies are supplyingadditional data and making recommendations on labeling.
Financing was supplied by a syndicate of international banks.
All employees were supplied with protective clothing.
supply.translation[3].definitions[0].def: an amount of something that is available to be sold, bought, used etc
supply.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The quality of the locallabour supply has helped to keep his company growing.
One-quarter of the nation’soil supply is shipped via the pipeline.
Coal inventories at the end of March were 390,000 metric tons, a 14-day supply.
During times of rapid growth demand for aircraft maintenance resources also tends to outstrip supply.
supply.translation[3].definitions[1].def: if something is in short supply, very little of it is available
supply.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Pricing information is in short supply because computer makers don’t like to talk about the latest trends.
The building projects are behind schedule and construction materials in desperately short supply.
supply.translation[3].definitions[2].def: a system that provides water, gas etc
supply.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: Thepublic water supply company said the charge was related to its environmental testing laboratory.
supply.translation[3].definitions[3].exa: There were some difficulties in the supply of raw materials.
